awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites - Type II: Von Liebig Center as Type II Renewal I-corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from the University of California San Diego (UCSD) creates an extension and expansion of their current I-Corps Site. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

This Site is the outcome of a Type II proposal from UCSD. There are two types of I-Corps Site proposals: Type I - Type I proposals are submitted by institutions that have not had prior funding as an I-Corps Site; Type II - Type II proposals are submitted by institutions that have had prior funding as an I-Corps Site. The UCSD Type II project proposed continuation and expansion of USCD's existing I-Corps Site, expanding target teams from 30 to 50 annually, integrating collaboration with the existing StartupXX program to nurture female entrepreneurs, adding leadership and team dynamics workshops in collaboration with an existing center on campus, and extending mentoring for I-Corps teams by six months. The Site also builds on a solid track record of success from first round I-Corps Site funding. The extensions to the existing Site are well-conceived, with clearly defined goals, and push the envelope of programming with the requested new funding. Their Site effectively leverages and integrates complementary existing programs, across disciplines, in a strong campus and regional ecosystem.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
At UC San Diego, we envision an ecosystem where commercialization that creates significant market impact is an “expected and essential outcome” of our deep-tech university research.

The Institute for the Global Entrepreneur (IGE) is a formal collaboration between the UC San Diego Jacobs School of Engineering and Rady School of Management. Its mission is to inspire and train entrepreneurial technology leaders and accelerate the translation of technologies to fuel the economy and benefit society.

 

Significant Legacy and Presidential Recognition

NSF I-Corps was first introduced on campus as part of the educational offerings of the Jacobs School of Engineering’s Von Liebig Entrepreneur Center, established in 2001, as a Proof-of-Concept center to facilitate and foster the exchange of ideas between university innovators and industry. The center was recognized nationally by the Kauffman Foundation as one of the first of its kind as early as 2008.

Starting in 2011, as one of the first four NSF I-Corps sites, UC San Diego built a world-class program and its resulting reputation - culminating in the training of teams that had virtually automatic acceptance into the National cohorts. Ultimately in August of 2015, these efforts resulted in one of our teams having the distinct honor of participating in the first-ever White House Demo Day, hosted by President Barack Obama.

 

Evolution and Expanded Impact

In 2016, the Jacobs School of Engineering and Rady School of Management jointly formed IGE to evolve and expand the mission of the Von Liebig Center to include the acceleration of student, faculty, alums and researcher-based startups and provide both the business and technical support necessary for deep-tech founders to raise their first institutional startup funding.

Over 400 teams and startups have participated in IGE programs, raising over $100 million in venture and grant funding. More than 250 of these teams have benefited from the NSF I-Corps program. We work closely with our startup founders, from exploration to business scaling. Our training programs vary from entry-level workshops to focused accelerators that support teams for up to 24 months.

The NSF I-Corps program has consistently evolved over the course of our site award from an education program into a foundation for multiple accelerators on campus. It has been instrumental in creating an environment where teams have successfully developed life-saving medical technologies in our MedTechAccelerator as well as environmentally sustainable blue and green technologies in collaboration with famed institutions such as the Scripps Institution of Oceanography.

 

Market Informed Research

IGE has consistently expanded the envelope of I-Corps by reaching out to community teams, developing cohorts for under-represented startup founders, and promoting our site activities to regional collaborators for the good of the entire San Diego entrepreneurial ecosystem.

We strongly believe that NSF I-Corps empowers entrepreneurs with the concepts of Product/Market Fit and Customer Discovery – providing a toolset for developing a new and exciting brand of “customer-influenced, market-informed” research. The resulting increased market awareness is now influencing not only how our startups apply existing IP, but also influences their future research directions.


Looking To The Future

As our site award concludes, we are encouraged by the possibilities provided by our transition to the NSF Desert and Pacific Region Hub. It’s a huge win for collaboration and an expansion of our network - partnering with several top western state research universities is already resulting in collaborations on many fronts.

We envision our partner-led cohorts to grow over the coming years, with our MedTech focus growing from devices to diagnostics, therapeutics, and the use of AI in areas of drug discovery. We see our sustainability focus evolving into several subcategories, such as clean energy, decarbonization, materials, and smart manufacturing.

We will continue our outreach to other research institutions. We recommended our fellow regional university partner, San Diego State University, be invited to participate as the newest hub member, based on their strong research programs, their community involvement, and their connections to other California state university programs.

We will also continue to increase our network of mentors, many of whom have gone on to join the management structure of our startup teams. We look forward to benefiting from more new collaborations with “second generation” startups founders, those coming back to NSF I-Corps for their second startup ideas.

NSF I-Corps will always be a foundation for our success. This journey from proof of concept to market-informed research has been a direct result of the ideas and efforts of the NSF and its visionaries, many of whom are responsible for the success of countless startups across the nation. We are honored to be a part of this journey.


Last Modified: 08/23/2024
Modified by: Sujit Dey
